article:
'Shoal Lake 39 First Nation' is an Ojibwa or Anishinaabe First Nation, located
along the northwestern shores of Shoal Lake, Ontario. http://firstnation.ca/shoal-lake-no-39-
iskatewizaagegan [http://pse5-esd5.ainc-
inac.gc.ca/FNP/Main/Search/FNMain.aspx?BAND_NUMBER=154&lang=e First Nation
profile from Indian and Northern Affairs Canada] It is officially known as
'Iskatewizaagegan #39 Independent First Nation'. The total registered population
of this First Nation is 585, of which 297 live on its own reserves. They are
governed by a chief and council, with their current Chief Eli Mandamin having
been re-elected in March 2010 for a two-year term.

In April 2008, the chief of Shoal Lake 39 complained that the sewage treatment
plant built for the community in 2000 had no running water to help maintain
cleanliness, and that other problems with the plant could lead to a complete shut-
down, resulting in raw sewage entering the lake from which Winnipeg has been
drawing its drinking water for almost 100 years. [http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/story/2008/04/21/shoal-
lake.html Lake that supplies Winnipeg's water threatened by sewage: chief]. CBC
News, 21 April 2008. Retrieved 13 September 2011. In June 2009, Chief
Mandamin and some community members demonstrated on the Trans-Canada Highway
near their home reserve, to show their grievances with a highway-twinning
project planned by the Ontario government. They also expressed frustration with
the fact that the City of Winnipeg has never made an agreement with Shoal Lake
39 regarding the water that is drawn from Shoal Lake to service Winnipeg
citizens, although the adjacent Shoal Lake 40 First Nation did have an agreement
settled in 1989. [http://www.wawataynews.ca/archive/all/2009/7/9/Water-highway-issues-
raised-in-Shoal-Lake-39-protest_17597 Water, highway issues raised in Shoal Lake
39 protest.] Wawatay News Online, 9 July 2009. Retrieved 14 September
2011.

In 2011, Iskatewizaagegan #39 First Nation voiced its concern over the plans for
the City of Winnipeg to sell its water to outlying communities. That water
originates in Shoal Lake, near the reserves of this First Nation, and the
natives are seeking monetary compensation, or other equivalent forms of redress,
for the many hardships they have endured over the years. The water taken out of
Shoal Lake for the aqueduct has required artificial maintenance of lake levels,
leading to loss of fishing and wild rice resources, among other difficulties
arising from the loss of sovereignty over the land and water. The leaders of
this #39 band have threatened to cut off the Winnipeg water supply by blocking
the aquatic entrance to Shoal Lake. [http://winnipeg.ctv.ca/servlet/an/loca-
l/CTVNews/20110907/wpg_shoal_lake_110709/20110907/?hub=WinnipegHome First Nation
community along Shoal Lake considers cutting off Winnipeg water supply in
protest]. CTV Winnipeg, 7 September 2011. Retrieved 13 September 2011. The
neighboring Shoal Lake 40 First Nation stated that they were not willing to take
such drastic measures in achieving their objectives, before negotiating with
various levels of government. [http://www.kenoradailyminerandnews.com/Artic-
leDisplay.aspx?e=3295463 Shoal Lake 40 says fight with Winnipeg over water is
theirs]. Miner & News, Kenora, 12 September 2011. Retrieved 13 September
2011.

Iskatewizaagegan First Nation has now taken this matter of Winnipeg's water
usage to the Manitoba Court of Queen's Bench. In a legal petition filed on 14
March 2012, the First Nation is asking the court to set aside a December 2011
decision by the City of Winnipeg to enter into service-sharing agreements,
including one nearing completion with West St. Paul. The Shoal Lake No. 39 band
also wants the court to order the city to refrain from any more negotiations
until it reaches an agreement with the First Nation on how the water may be
used. This First Nation has long maintained Winnipeg did not obtain its consent
as far back as 1919, although a neighbouring band, Shoal Lake No. 40, has no
such dispute with the city. [http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/local/reserve-fighting-city-in-
court-142746155.html Reserve fighting city in court]. Winnipeg Free Press, 15
March 2012. Retrieved 15 March 2012.

Four Reserves are attached to this First Nation. http://pse5-esd5.ainc-
inac.gc.ca/FNP/Main/Search/FNReserves.aspx?BAND_NUMBER=154&lang=eng They are:

*'Agency 30', shared with 12 other First Nations *'Shoal Lake 34B2', shared with
Shoal Lake 40 First Nation *'Shoal Lake 39', partly located in Manitoba adjacent
to the north of Shoal Lake *'Shoal Lake 39A', northwest of Lake of the Woods
categories: Articles created via the Article Wizard
